markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Weapon 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Reinforced Frame](/Weapons.aspx?ID=230)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Agile" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=170" />
<trait label="Attached" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=171" />
<trait label="Free-Hand" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=181" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Grand Bazaar](/Sources.aspx?ID=100) pg. 72</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 5 sp

**Damage** 1d4 B

**Bulk** —
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 1

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Category** Simple

**Group** [Club](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=5)
</row>

</column>

---

The chair's wheels have been reinforced with tough, metal rims or a metal cap. While in the chair, you gain a wheel Strike. Your wheel deals 1d4 bludgeoning damage and has the [agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [attached](/Traits.aspx?ID=171), and [free-hand](/Traits.aspx?ID=181) traits. A reinforced wheel is a simple melee weapon in the [club](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=5) weapon group. You can etch weapon runes onto reinforced wheels. A wheelchair can only have one attached weapon.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).

<document level="2" id="weapon-group-5" />
name: Reinforced Frame
